description.short: Measures vulnerability to attackers who exploit commitment/consistency principle to escalate from small initial requests to major security compromises
description.context: When organizations make small initial security exceptions or commitments, cognitive dissonance creates psychological pressure to maintain consistency with prior decisions, enabling attackers to progressively escalate access, privileges, or policy violations through foot-in-door techniques and sunk cost exploitation.
description.impact: Organizations with high susceptibility experience vendor access creep, privilege escalation chains, normalized exception patterns, and inability to reverse poor security decisions due to sunk cost fallacy. Historical incidents include Target 2013 vendor access escalation ($200M+ impact) and progressive BEC campaigns that start small and escalate over weeks.
description.psychological_basis: Cialdini's commitment/consistency principle (2007) - humans have deep desire to appear consistent with prior actions. Festinger's cognitive dissonance theory (1957) - psychological discomfort when reversing previous commitments. Staw's escalation of commitment research (1976) - sunk cost fallacy drives continued investment in failing courses. Sharot fMRI studies (2010) show reward pathway activation when maintaining consistency, creating neurological pressure against reversal.

scoring.formula: Final_Score = (w1 Ã— Quick_Assessment + w2 Ã— Conversation_Depth + w3 Ã— Red_Flags) Ã— Interdependency_Multiplier

green.label: Low Vulnerability - Resilient
green.description: Automated exception sunset policies with mandatory review cycles. Security investments evaluated independently regardless of sunk costs. Vendor access boundaries enforced with escalation pattern detection. Decision revision protocols explicitly protect course corrections. Regular audits identify and terminate escalating exception sequences.

yellow.label: Moderate Vulnerability - Developing
yellow.description: Some exception review processes exist but inconsistent enforcement. Security decisions occasionally reference prior commitments. Vendor access monitored but escalation patterns not systematically detected. Limited ability to reverse previous security decisions. Informal awareness of sunk cost bias.

red.label: High Vulnerability - Critical
red.description: Strong cultural pressure to maintain consistency with prior security decisions. Sunk cost fallacy drives continued investment in ineffective security tools. Vendor access creep normalized as 'relationship deepening'. No systematic review of escalating exceptions. Security decisions defended based on prior commitments rather than current threat landscape.

rule_based.formula: R_3.2(t) = 1 if ESI > 0.2 AND Sequence_Length > 3, else 0
rule_based.description: Binary detection based on Escalation Sequence Index exceeding threshold with sufficient sequence length

anomaly_score.description: Escalation Sequence Index measuring average risk increase per step in commitment sequence

variables.Risk_i: risk score of request i in sequence
variables.log_ratio: logarithmic risk ratio between consecutive requests

priors.P_0: baseline approval probability (0.10 for high-risk requests)

temporal_decay.description: Exponential smoothing with 4-hour time constant for escalation sequence detection

commitment_escalation.formula: C(n) = C_0 Â· âˆ(1 + Î±_i Â· consistency_pressure_i)
commitment_escalation.description: Cumulative commitment magnitude after n escalation steps
commitment_escalation.interpretation: Commitment grows multiplicatively with each step, creating exponential resistance to reversal
commitment_escalation.alpha_i: consistency pressure coefficient for step i (typically 0.15-0.35)

components.P_0: baseline acceptance probability without prior commitment
components.C_n: commitment magnitude after n steps from commitment_escalation formula

foot_in_door_effect.interpretation: Acceptance probability increases exponentially with cumulative commitment ratio

escalation_sequence_index.description: Measures average logarithmic risk increase per step in escalation sequence
escalation_sequence_index.interpretation: ESI > 0.2 indicates systematic risk escalation; ESI > 0.5 indicates aggressive exploitation

ESI.calculation: Escalation Sequence Index from sequential risk increases
ESI.query: SELECT AVG(LOG(risk_i+1 / risk_i)) FROM (SELECT risk_level, LAG(risk_level) OVER (PARTITION BY requester_id ORDER BY timestamp) as prev_risk FROM exception_requests WHERE requester_id=? AND time_window='90d') WHERE prev_risk IS NOT NULL

Sequence_Length.calculation: Count of consecutive related exception requests
Sequence_Length.query: SELECT COUNT(*) FROM exception_requests WHERE requester_id=? AND related_sequence_id=? AND timestamp > NOW() - INTERVAL '90 days'

C_n.query: SELECT EXP(SUM(LOG(1 + 0.25 * consistency_pressure))) as commitment FROM exception_sequence WHERE sequence_id=?

sections.title: QUICK ASSESSMENT

items.title: Security Exception Review and Sunset Process
items.question: How does your organization review and terminate security exceptions that were granted previously?

options.label: Automated exception sunset system with mandatory review cycles (30/60/90 day), exceptions auto-expire unless re-justified independently
Manual exception review occurs but inconsistent frequency or no automatic expiration
Exceptions remain in place indefinitely once granted or 'we don't want to break what's working'

items.evidence_required: Exception sunset policy, automated expiration logs, review cycle documentation

items.title: Security Tool Effectiveness Evaluation
items.question: How do you evaluate whether to continue investing in existing security tools and solutions?

options.label: Independent effectiveness evaluations that explicitly ignore sunk costs, tools discontinued if not meeting current needs regardless of prior investment
Effectiveness reviewed but prior investment influences renewal decisions
Continued investment justified by prior spending or 'we've already invested so much in this tool'

items.evidence_required: Security tool ROI analysis, discontinuation decisions, sunk cost awareness documentation
items.soc_mapping: Security investment tracking and effectiveness metrics

items.title: Vendor Access Scope Boundary Enforcement
items.question: When vendors request expanded access beyond their original scope, how are these escalation requests handled?

options.label: Strict boundary enforcement with independent evaluation of expansion requests, automated detection of scope creep patterns
Expansion requests reviewed but prior access history influences approvals
Vendor access naturally expands over time as 'relationship deepens' or 'we already trust them'

items.evidence_required: Vendor access boundary policy, scope expansion logs, escalation detection reports
items.soc_mapping: Vendor access scope analysis from vendor_access_logs

items.title: Repeated Exception Request Pattern Detection
items.question: When the same person, team, or vendor repeatedly requests security exceptions, what triggers investigation?

options.label: Automated escalation pattern detection alerts after 3+ sequential exceptions with increasing risk levels (ESI > 0.2)
Exception patterns noticed informally but no systematic detection or thresholds
No tracking of exception sequences or 'they have legitimate reasons for exceptions'

items.evidence_required: Escalation pattern detection system, ESI calculation logs, investigation triggers

items.title: Long-term Security Investment Tracking
items.question: How do you track cumulative investment (time, money, political capital) in security initiatives to identify sunk cost vulnerabilities?

options.label: Systematic tracking of cumulative security investments with explicit sunk cost bias awareness and reversal protection protocols
General awareness of major investments but no formal sunk cost vulnerability tracking
No tracking of cumulative commitments or sunk cost bias not recognized as security issue

items.evidence_required: Security investment database, sunk cost tracking, decision reversal protocols

items.title: Adapting to Audit Findings vs. Defending Prior Decisions
items.question: When audits identify issues with previous security decisions, how does your organization respond?

options.label: Rapid course correction with explicit decision revision protocols that protect employees who reverse prior commitments
Some adaptation occurs but significant effort spent defending or justifying prior decisions
Primary response is defending consistency with prior decisions or 'we made that choice for good reasons at the time'

items.evidence_required: Audit response documentation, decision reversal examples, revision protocol documentation
items.soc_mapping: Audit finding response patterns from audit_finding_logs

items.title: Project and Initiative Scope Creep Prevention
items.question: How do you prevent security projects from experiencing scope creep where initial small commitments expand into major initiatives?

options.label: Formal scope boundaries with change control processes, escalation sequence monitoring, explicit re-authorization required for scope expansion
General scope management but no specific escalation sequence detection
Scope naturally expands from initial commitments or 'we're already this far along, might as well continue'

items.evidence_required: Scope change control process, escalation detection for projects, re-authorization requirements
items.soc_mapping: Project scope expansion patterns from change management logs

items.title: Automated Commitment Escalation Detection
items.question: What technical controls detect when small initial security decisions are being systematically escalated over time?

options.label: Automated ESI calculation and alerting when Escalation Sequence Index > 0.2 with sequence length > 3 requests
Manual review can identify escalation patterns but no automated detection or thresholds
No technical controls for detecting commitment escalation sequences

items.evidence_required: Escalation detection system configuration, ESI alerting rules, detection examples
items.soc_mapping: R_3.2(t) detection events from security monitoring platform

sections.instructions: Select ONE option for each question. Each answer contributes to the weighted final score. Evidence should be documented for audit trail.

items.text: Walk me through what happens to security exceptions after they're granted. How do they get reviewed and terminated?

scoring_guidance.green: Detailed automated sunset process with specific review cycles, recent examples of exceptions auto-expired, independent re-justification required
scoring_guidance.yellow: Manual review process exists but irregular or exceptions persist beyond original justification period
scoring_guidance.red: Exceptions become permanent once granted or 'we don't revisit approved exceptions'

followups.text: Show me your oldest currently active security exception - why is it still in place?
What happens when someone tries to terminate an exception that's been in place for a long time?

items.text: Tell me about a time when someone requested multiple security exceptions over a period of weeks or months - what pattern did you observe?

scoring_guidance.green: Specific example where escalation pattern was detected and investigated, ESI calculation or similar analysis performed
scoring_guidance.yellow: Pattern noticed in hindsight but no systematic detection at the time
scoring_guidance.red: Cannot recall any escalation sequences or 'each exception is evaluated independently'

followups.text: How do your systems flag when exception requests are forming an escalating sequence?
At what point in an escalation sequence do you investigate the overall pattern rather than individual requests?

items.text: How has your largest vendor's access scope changed since you first granted them access? Walk me through that evolution.

scoring_guidance.green: Documented access history showing strict boundary enforcement, scope expansions independently justified, expansion requests denied with examples
scoring_guidance.yellow: Access has expanded but with some justification, boundary enforcement inconsistent
scoring_guidance.red: Access naturally expanded over time as relationship deepened or 'they already had access to X, so Y made sense'

followups.text: Can you show me your vendor access boundary documentation and scope expansion logs?
When was the last time you reduced or revoked vendor access that had been previously granted?

items.text: When a vendor says 'we already have access to system A, we just need system B to complete the integration' - how do you evaluate that request?

scoring_guidance.green: Independent risk evaluation ignoring prior access, explicit recognition of foot-in-door technique, recent examples of denials despite prior access
scoring_guidance.yellow: Request evaluated but prior access is positive factor in approval decision
scoring_guidance.red: Prior access creates presumption of approval or 'it would be inconsistent to deny after already granting A'

followups.text: Do your approval workflows flag when requests reference prior access grants?
How do you protect against the foot-in-door technique in vendor access management?

items.text: Tell me about a security tool or initiative where you've invested significant resources over multiple years - how do you decide whether to continue?

scoring_guidance.green: Explicit sunk cost awareness, independent effectiveness evaluation, documented examples of discontinuing initiatives despite prior investment
scoring_guidance.yellow: Effectiveness considered but prior investment influences continuation decisions
scoring_guidance.red: Continuation justified primarily by prior investment or 'we've already spent so much on this'

followups.text: Can you show me a recent decision to discontinue a security tool where significant prior investment existed?
How do your investment decision protocols explicitly counteract sunk cost fallacy?

items.text: When audit findings or security assessments contradict previous security decisions your organization made, what typically happens?

scoring_guidance.green: Rapid course correction with decision revision protocols, recent examples of reversing prior commitments based on new information, explicit protection for employees who change course
scoring_guidance.yellow: Some adaptation but also effort defending previous decisions, mixed responses
scoring_guidance.red: Primary response is defending consistency or 'those decisions were made for good reasons we still stand by'

followups.text: Show me the last audit finding that required reversing a previous security commitment - what was the internal discussion?
Are employees protected from blame when they reverse previous security decisions based on new information?

items.text: How does your organizational culture view changing course or reversing previous security decisions?

scoring_guidance.green: Culture celebrates adaptive decision-making, explicit training on sunk cost fallacy and commitment escalation, recent examples of praised course corrections
scoring_guidance.yellow: Mixed cultural messages, some acceptance of course changes but also pressure for consistency
scoring_guidance.red: Strong cultural pressure for consistency with prior decisions, course reversals seen as weakness or poor initial judgment

followups.text: What training do employees receive on recognizing commitment escalation traps and sunk cost fallacy in security decisions?
Can you describe a situation where someone was praised for reversing a previous security commitment?

solutions.title: Automated Exception Sunset System
solutions.description: Technical controls that automatically expire security exceptions on predetermined schedules, requiring independent re-justification for renewal
solutions.implementation: Deploy exception lifecycle management platform with automated expiration workflows (30/60/90 day cycles based on risk). Exceptions auto-revoke unless re-justified independently of prior approval. Integration with access control, firewall, PAM, and policy enforcement systems. Alert stakeholders 7 days before expiration with re-justification requirements.
solutions.technical_controls: Exception tracking database, automated expiration workflows, access control API integration, re-justification requirement enforcement, sunset alert system

solutions.title: Vendor Access Boundary Monitoring
solutions.description: Systematic tracking and enforcement of vendor access scope boundaries with automated detection of escalation patterns
solutions.implementation: Define explicit access boundaries for each vendor relationship in vendor management system. Implement automated scope monitoring that flags expansion requests. Calculate ESI for vendor access sequences. Require independent risk evaluation for scope expansion ignoring prior access grants. Monthly vendor access boundary audit reports.
solutions.technical_controls: Vendor access scope definitions, boundary violation detection, ESI calculation for vendor sequences, automated escalation alerts, scope audit dashboards

solutions.title: Security Investment Review Process
solutions.description: Independent effectiveness evaluation framework that explicitly counteracts sunk cost fallacy in security tool and initiative decisions
solutions.implementation: Quarterly security investment effectiveness review with explicit sunk cost bias awareness training for decision-makers. Independent evaluation criteria that exclude prior investment from continuation decisions. Documented decision revision protocols protecting employees who recommend discontinuation. ROI analysis based on current effectiveness, not cumulative investment.
solutions.technical_controls: Investment tracking system, effectiveness metrics dashboard, sunk cost bias training modules, decision revision documentation, discontinuation approval workflows

solutions.title: Independent Access Review Teams
solutions.description: Separate review teams that evaluate escalating access requests without knowledge of prior approval history to eliminate consistency pressure
solutions.implementation: Establish independent review committee for high-risk access requests that operates without visibility into prior exception history for same requester. Blind review process removes consistency pressure. Committee training on foot-in-door techniques and escalation exploitation. Quarterly rotation of review team members.
solutions.technical_controls: Blind review workflow system, historical data masking, independent committee structure, decision tracking without requester history exposure

solutions.title: Escalation Pattern Detection System
solutions.description: Automated calculation of Escalation Sequence Index (ESI) with alerting when commitment escalation patterns exceed thresholds
solutions.implementation: Deploy ESI calculation engine that analyzes exception requests, access grants, and policy violations for escalation sequences. Alert security teams when ESI > 0.2 AND Sequence_Length > 3. Pattern visualization dashboard showing commitment escalation chains. Integration with SIEM for correlation with other attack indicators. Monthly ESI reporting to security leadership.
solutions.technical_controls: ESI calculation engine, escalation sequence detection algorithms, automated alerting (R_3.2(t) threshold), pattern visualization dashboard, SIEM integration

solutions.title: Decision Revision Protocols
solutions.description: Explicit organizational policies and psychological safety frameworks that protect and encourage course corrections when new information emerges
solutions.implementation: Formal decision revision protocol that celebrates adaptive security decision-making. Training programs on commitment escalation traps, sunk cost fallacy, and cognitive dissonance in security. Explicit protection policies for employees who reverse previous commitments based on new threat intelligence or audit findings. Leadership communication emphasizing that course corrections demonstrate strength, not weakness. Recognition programs for exemplary decision reversals.
solutions.technical_controls: Decision revision workflow system, commitment bias training modules, employee protection policy documentation, course correction recognition tracking

risk_scenarios.title: Vendor Access Escalation (Target 2013 Pattern)
risk_scenarios.description: Attackers gain initial limited vendor access, then systematically escalate scope through consistency pressure, referencing prior approvals to justify each expansion until achieving network-wide compromise
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Initial legitimate vendor relationship for limited purpose (HVAC monitoring, badge system, specific application), followed by incremental access expansion requests invoking prior trust
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Foot-in-door effect + consistency pressure: P_accept(n) = P_0 Â· (C(n)/C_0)^Î² where each approval increases commitment magnitude exponentially
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Target 2013 - HVAC vendor access escalated from building management to network-wide access through series of small expansions, leading to 40M+ credit card breach and $200M+ total impact

risk_scenarios.title: Exception Normalization Attack
risk_scenarios.description: Attackers request small, seemingly reasonable security exceptions that become permanent, then reference these precedents to justify progressively larger policy violations
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Initial low-risk exception request (temporary firewall rule, one-time access grant, brief monitoring bypass) that remains active indefinitely, then invoked as precedent for larger exceptions
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Commitment escalation: C(n) = C_0 Â· âˆ(1 + Î±_i Â· consistency_pressure_i) creates exponential growth in commitment magnitude and resistance to reversal
risk_scenarios.historical_example: BEC campaigns that start with small invoice approval irregularities, establish pattern of exceptions, then escalate to major fraudulent wire transfers invoking 'we've done this before' consistency pressure

risk_scenarios.title: Sunk Cost Security Tool Persistence
risk_scenarios.description: Organizations continue investing in ineffective security tools due to prior investment, while attackers exploit known vulnerabilities in those outdated systems
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Attackers identify organizations using outdated or ineffective security tools (detectable through technical fingerprinting, job postings, vendor partnerships), exploit known limitations while organization resists replacement due to sunk costs
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Sunk cost fallacy: continued investment justified by prior spending rather than current effectiveness, creating persistent security gaps
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Multiple breaches where organizations maintained ineffective legacy security tools for 3-5 years beyond useful life due to sunk cost bias, while attackers exploited well-known bypasses

risk_scenarios.title: Privilege Escalation Through Commitment Chains
risk_scenarios.description: Insider threats or compromised accounts escalate privileges through sequences of small requests, each justified by prior approvals, until achieving administrative access
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Initial legitimate low-privilege access, followed by systematic requests for incremental privilege increases, each referencing prior grants and establishing consistency pressure on approvers
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Foot-in-door effect combined with authority/reciprocity if requester has provided favors or has authority position: convergent vulnerability multiplier of 3.2x
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Insider threat cases where employees escalated from basic access to domain admin over 6-12 months through 8-12 small privilege requests, each approved due to consistency with prior pattern
